included(base)

This method is called when the module is included.

On inclusion, we do a nifty bit of meta programming and make the including class behave like ActiveRBAC‘s User class without some of the validation. Extensive validation can be done by including the Validation class.

[Source]

 28:         base.class_eval do

125:           # This method writes the attribute "password" to the hashed version. It is 
126:           # called in the after_validation hook set by the "after_validation" command
127:           # above.
128:           # The password is only encrypted when no errors occured on validation, the
129:           # password is new and the password is not nil.
130:           # This method also sets the "password_salt" property's value used in 
131:           # User#hash_string.
132:           # After encryption, the password's "new" state is reset and the confirmation
133:           # is cleared. The password hash's type will also be set to "not new" since
134:           # we get problems with double validation (as it happens when using save!)
135:           # otherwise.
136:           def encrypt_password
137:             if errors.count == 0 and @new_password and not password.nil?
138:               # generate a new 10-char long hash only Base64 encoded so things are compatible
139:               self.password_salt = [Array.new(10){rand(256).chr}.join].pack("m")[0..9]; 
140: 
141:               # write encrypted password to object property
142:               write_attribute(:password, hash_string(password))
143: 
144:               # mark password as "not new" any more
145:               @new_password = false
146:               password_confirmation = nil
147:               
148:               # mark the hash type as "not new" any more
149:               @new_hash_type = false
150:             end
151:           end
152: 
153:           # This method returns all roles assigned to the given user - including
154:           # the ones he gets by being assigned a child role (i.e. the parents)
155:           # and the one he gets through his groups (inheritance is also considered)
156:           # here.
157:           def all_roles
158:             result = Array.new
159: 
160:             for role in self.roles
161:               result << role.ancestors_and_self
162:             end
163: 
164:             for group in self.groups

240:           # This method expects the token for the current user. If the token is
241:           # correct, the user's state will be set to "confirmed" and the associated
242:           # "user_registration" record will be removed.
243:           # Returns "true" on success and "false" on failure/or the user is already
244:           # confirmed and/or has no "user_registration" record.
245:           def confirm_registration(token)
246:             return false if self.user_registration.nil?
247:             return false if user_registration.token != token
248:             return false unless state_transition_allowed?(state, User.states['confirmed'])
249: 
250:             self.state = User.states['confirmed']
251:             self.save!
252:             user_registration.destroy
253: 
254:             return true
255:           end

337:           # Sets the last login time and saves the object. Note: Must currently be 
338:           # called explicitely!
339:           def did_log_in
340:             self.last_logged_in_at = DateTime.now
341:             self.class.execute_without_timestamps { save }
342:           end
343: 
344:           # Returns true if the the state transition from "from" state to "to" state 
345:           # is valid. Returns false otherwise. +new_state+ must be the integer value 
346:           # of the state as returned by +User.states['state_name']+.
347:           #
348:           # Note that currently no permission checking is included here; It does not 
349:           # matter what permissions the currently logged in user has, only that the
350:           # state transition is legal in principle.
351:           def state_transition_allowed?(from, to)
352:             from = from.to_i
353:             to = to.to_i
354: 
355:             return true if from == to # allow keeping state
356: 
357:             return case from
358:               when User.states['unconfirmed']
359:                 true
360:               when User.states['confirmed']
361:                 [ User.states['retrieved_password'], User.states['locked'], User.states['deleted'] ].include?(to)
362:               when User.states['locked']
363:                 [ User.states['confirmed'], User.states['deleted'] ].include?(to)
364:               when User.states['deleted']
365:                 [ User.states['confirmed'] ].include?(to)
366:               when User.states['retrieved_password']
367:                 [ User.states['confirmed'], User.states['locked'], User.states['deleted'] ].include?(to)
368:               when 0
369:                 User.states.value?(to)
370:               else
371:                 false
372:             end
373:           end
374: 
375:           # After validation, the password should be encrypted  
376:           after_validation :encrypt_password
377: 
378:           protected
379:             # This method allows to execute a block while deactivating timestamp
380:             # updating.
381:             def self.execute_without_timestamps
382:               begin
383: 
384:                 User.record_timestamps = false
385:   
386:                 yield
387:                 
388:               ensure
389:                 User.record_timestamps = true
390:               end
391:             end
392: 
393:             # Model Validation
394: 
395:             validates_presence_of   :login, :password, :password_hash_type, :state, #:email
396:                                     :message => 'must be given'
397: 
398:             validates_uniqueness_of :login, 
399:                                     :message => 'is the name of an already existing user.'
400: 
401:             # Overriding this method to do some more validation: Password equals 
402:             # password_confirmation, state an password hash type being in the range
403:             # of allowed values.
404:             def validate
405:               # validate state and password has type to be in the valid range of values
406:               errors.add(:password_hash_type, "must be in the list of hash types.") unless User.password_hash_types.include? password_hash_type
407:               # check that the state transition is valid
408:               errors.add(:state, "must be a valid new state from the current state.") unless state_transition_allowed?(@old_state, state)
409: 
410:               # validate the password
411:               if @new_password and not password.nil?
412:                 errors.add(:password, 'must match the confirmation.') unless password_confirmation == password
413:               end
414: 
415:               # check that the password hash type has not been set if no new password
416:               # has been provided
417:               if @new_hash_type and (!@new_password or password.nil?) then
418:                 errors.add(:password_hash_type, 'cannot be changed unless a new password has been provided.')
419:               end
420:             end
421: 
422:           private
423:             # This method returns a hash which contains a mapping of user states 
424:             # valid by default and their description.
425:             def self.default_states
426:               {
427:                 'unconfirmed' => 1,
428:                 'confirmed' => 2,
429:                 'locked' => 3,
430:                 'deleted' => 4,
431:                 # The user has just retrieved his password and he must now
432:                 # it. The user cannot anything in this state but change his
433:                 # password after having logged in and retrieve another one.
434:                 'retrieved_password' => 5
435:               }
436:             end
437: 
438:             # This method returns an array which contains all valid hash types.
439:             def self.default_password_hash_types
440:               [ 'md5' ]
441:             end
442: 
443:             # Hashes the given parameter by the selected hashing method. It uses the
444:             # "password_salt" property's value to make the hashing more secure.
445:             def hash_string(value)
446:               return case password_hash_type
447:                      when 'md5' then Digest::MD5.hexdigest(value + self.password_salt)
448:                      end
449:             end 
450:         end
451:       end

This method expects the token for the current user. If the token is correct, the user‘s state will be set to "confirmed" and the associated "user_registration" record will be removed. Returns "true" on success and "false" on failure/or the user is already confirmed and/or has no "user_registration" record.

encrypt_password()

This method writes the attribute "password" to the hashed version. It is called in the after_validation hook set by the "after_validation" command above. The password is only encrypted when no errors occured on validation, the password is new and the password is not nil. This method also sets the "password_salt" property‘s value used in User#hash_string. After encryption, the password‘s "new" state is reset and the confirmation is cleared. The password hash‘s type will also be set to "not new" since we get problems with double validation (as it happens when using save!) otherwise.

[Source]

     # File vendor/plugins/active_rbac/lib/active_rbac_mixins/user_mixins.rb, line 136
136:           def encrypt_password
137:             if errors.count == 0 and @new_password and not password.nil?
138:               # generate a new 10-char long hash only Base64 encoded so things are compatible
139:               self.password_salt = [Array.new(10){rand(256).chr}.join].pack("m")[0..9]; 
140: 
141:               # write encrypted password to object property
142:               write_attribute(:password, hash_string(password))
143: 
144:               # mark password as "not new" any more
145:               @new_password = false
146:               password_confirmation = nil
147:               
148:               # mark the hash type as "not new" any more
149:               @new_hash_type = false
150:             end
151:           end

state_transition_allowed?(from, to)

Returns true if the the state transition from "from" state to "to" state is valid. Returns false otherwise. new_state must be the integer value of the state as returned by +User.states[‘state_name’]+.

Note that currently no permission checking is included here; It does not matter what permissions the currently logged in user has, only that the state transition is legal in principle.

[Source]

     # File vendor/plugins/active_rbac/lib/active_rbac_mixins/user_mixins.rb, line 351
351:           def state_transition_allowed?(from, to)
352:             from = from.to_i
353:             to = to.to_i
354: 
355:             return true if from == to # allow keeping state
356: 
357:             return case from
358:               when User.states['unconfirmed']
359:                 true
360:               when User.states['confirmed']
361:                 [ User.states['retrieved_password'], User.states['locked'], User.states['deleted'] ].include?(to)
362:               when User.states['locked']
363:                 [ User.states['confirmed'], User.states['deleted'] ].include?(to)
364:               when User.states['deleted']
365:                 [ User.states['confirmed'] ].include?(to)
366:               when User.states['retrieved_password']
367:                 [ User.states['confirmed'], User.states['locked'], User.states['deleted'] ].include?(to)
368:               when 0
369:                 User.states.value?(to)
370:               else
371:                 false
372:             end
373:           end
update_password(pass)

Method to update the password and confirmation at the same time. Call this method when you update the password from code and don‘t need password_confirmation - which should really only be used when data comes from forms.

A ussage example: 

  user = User.find(1)
  user.update_password "n1C3s3cUreP4sSw0rD"
  user.save
